goals: To introduce students to a wide range of philosophy and literature, including but not limited to Absolute Idealism, Victorian poetry, American modernism, and queer theory.
To encourage students to develop an interdisciplinary and transhistorical approach to engaging with literature and culture.
To strengthen students critical thinking and academic writing abilities.
To facilitate collaborative intellectual and creative interactions between students.
syllabus:
“The Unendurable is the Beginning of the Curve of Joy”: 

Love in Literature and Culture

National Taiwan Normal University, Fall 2022

Wednesdays, 9:20-12:10

Dr. Justin Prystash                                                 

Office:     Cheng 720                     

Office Hours: W 15:20-17:10; F 11:20-13:10; Virtual Meetings by Appointment

Email: jsprystash@gmail.com               

**Course Description**

This course seeks to investigate the seemingly ordinary yet elusive concept of love through a wide range of texts and media. After using Ronald de Sousa’s _Love: A Very Short Introduction_ to provide a brief panoramic overview of different approaches to the topic, we will read, watch, and listen to philosophy, poetry, novels, film, and music (mostly from the Romantic period forward) to see how love has been conceptualized and expressed. We will cover many gradients of love, from metaphysical love—the idealist conception of love as a fundamental structuring principle of the universe, a basic element of reality itself—down to passion and sexuality, the more fleshy, carnal, embodied aspects of love. We will consider both heterosexual love and non-normative, queer expressions of love and sexuality. We will find that love, to borrow Tennyson’s language, draws us “like a sinking star / Beyond the utmost bound of human thought.”          

**Texts**

Students should purchase the following texts, made available at _Bookman_ in Taipei (across from NTU); all others will be supplied by the professor.

Ronald de Sousa, _Love: A Very Short Introduction_ (Oxford UP)

Emily Brontë, _Wuthering Heights_ (Penguin)

Djuna Barnes, _Nightwood_ (Faber & Faber)

Iris Murdoch, _The Bell_ (Vintage)

**Assignments**

Attendance/Participation   20%

Seminar Paper (10+ pages) 80% 

**Attendance/Participation**

This is a graduate seminar. Seminars are not meant to be lecture-based, but discussion-based. That means you need to participate in order for us to have a successful seminar (it also means that I need to regularly fade away from the center of the class). Although I will guide our discussions, I expect you to come to class familiar with that week’s assigned reading(s), ready to ask questions and have fruitful discussions and debates. I will take attendance every week. I will also regularly hold in-class group “games” where you will analyze and/or synthesize passages from our texts and share your perspectives with the class. 

          
**Seminar Paper**

This is the usual assignment given at the end of a graduate seminar: an academic essay, similar in style and organization to published essays that appear in academic journals. They must focus on one of the texts we read this semester, they cannot be used in any other seminar, and they cannot be plagiarized.

**Schedule**

Week 1, 9/7: Introduction, Syllabus Review

Week 2, 9/14: Ronald de Sousa, _Love: A Very Short Introduction_

Week 3, 9/21: Plato, _Symposium_ and “The Allegory of the Cave”

Week 4, 9/28: From Frederick C. Beiser, _German Idealism_ and _Hegel_; Novalis, _Hymns to the Night_; Samuel Taylor Coleridge, “The Eolian Harp” 

Week 5, 10/5: Lord Byron, _Don Juan_, Canto I    

Week 6, 10/12: Emily Brontë, _Wuthering Heights_    

Week 7, 10/19: Emily Brontë, _Wuthering Heights_; Franz Liszt, _Liebesträume_

Week 8, 10/26: From F. H. Bradley, _Ethical Studies_; J. M. E. McTaggart, “The Further Determination of the Absolute” and “The Unreality of Time”; T. S. Eliot, “Burnt Norton”    

Week 9, 11/2: From Michel Foucault, _The History of Sexuality, Volume 1_; Djuna Barnes, _Nightwood_  

Week 10, 11/9: Djuna Barnes, _Nightwood_

Week 11, 11/16: From Eve Kosofsky Sedgwick, _Epistemology of the Closet_ (1990); Iris Murdoch, _The Bell_  

Week 12, 11/23: Iris Murdoch, _The Bell_

Week 13, 11/30: _Interstellar_ (2014, dir. Christopher Nolan)   

Week 14, 12/7: Contemporary Pop Music  

Week 15, 12/14: _Carol_ (dir. Todd Haynes)

Week 16, 12/21: Final Paper Due (No Class Meeting)
